instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: Cpu voltage present but no chime/boot
threads.message: I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board originally got stuck halfway through boot, replaced bios and it worked properly. After checking on it a few months later it now has <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> at 1.8 but doesn't chime/boot and no image, cpu does get slightly warm, takes around 5.5 watts a little over 250mA.

threads.title: Cpu voltage present but no chime/boot
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"replaced bios and it worked properly"
Did you properly clean ME that time???
Try known good working BIOS file, with clean ME.
Also check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
Clean/remove J6100...

threads.title: Cpu voltage present but no chime/boot
threads.message:
I used a file that had a clean ME and it booted and worked before this happend ( it used to get stuck loading)
Im not too sure what you mean by checking SPI Bus series, if you mean the resistors near the bios like <RESISTOR>R6120</RESISTOR> they all have the proper resistance and if you mean "is there continuity from the resistor to where it leads" they all check out

should i try a to load a clean bios again, would the bios somehow go bad?
last time i deleted and uploaded a new file to it

haven't done too much with bios so not sure exactly what to do.

threads.title: Cpu voltage present but no chime/boot
threads.message: You can only discard BIOS issue trying good file again...

threads.title: Cpu voltage present but no chime/boot
threads.message: Just tried new bios and same thing. I had a file that had clean ME and programmed it over the old one

threads.title: Cpu voltage present but no chime/boot
threads.message: looks like i had <RESISTOR>R7102</RESISTOR> on the board removed it and <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> was bad replaced and got green light same problem still no chime/boot

threads.title: Cpu voltage present but no chime/boot
threads.message:
Any history of the machine for these "few months"?
Any liquid sign?

threads.title: Cpu voltage present but no chime/boot
threads.message: Cant remember liquid it has been cleaned but there were bad components near <CHIP>U5620</CHIP>, replaced them and the chip, no change, no signs of corrosion I've went over the board a few times. Its been left on a shelf with some other boards for probably a month or 2

threads.title: Cpu voltage present but no chime/boot
threads.message:
If had liquid damage months ago, some component has been affected in time.
I recommend to reball SMC first.

If you don't find visible corroded component, heat CPU with quality flux; may have luck to be accumulated crap issue.

threads.title: Cpu voltage present but no chime/boot
threads.message: I think I'm going to leave this for now until i get time to do that thank you
